channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Take The Planet Money Summer School Quiz In Political Economy
item.description: Think you have what it takes to successfully manipulate the market and build a domestic industry from the ground up? If so, these eight questions stand between you and your Summer School diploma in Political Economy.
item.content:encoded: Think you have what it takes to successfully manipulate the market and build a domestic industry from the ground up? If so, these eight questions stand between you and your Summer School diploma in Political Economy.
item.dc:creator: Eric Mennel

item.title: Whatever happened to our sibling series? It's back! And guess who's the heir apparent
item.description: When parents die, sibling tensions can arise over inheritance. In many traditions, the oldest child used to get it all. In a part of Pakistan, there's a surprise twist: The youngest is the chosen one.
item.content:encoded:
When parents die, sibling tensions can arise over inheritance. In many traditions, the oldest child used to get it all. In a part of Pakistan, there's a surprise twist: The youngest is the chosen one.

(Image credit: Shayan Ali Khan)
item.dc:creator: Benazir Samad

item.title: Fed governor fights for her job. And, the DNC has a message for Democrats
item.description: Fed Governor Lisa Cook plans to fight to keep her job with a forthcoming lawsuit challenging President Trump. And, the DNC addresses the Democratic Party's challenges.
item.content:encoded:
Fed Governor Lisa Cook plans to fight to keep her job with a forthcoming lawsuit challenging President Trump. And, the DNC addresses the Democratic Party's challenges.

(Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: A 6-year-old girl from Gaza, a missing limb and a doctor's mission
item.description: How do you heal the wounds of war? That is the mission of Dr. Ghassan Abu-Sittah, a reconstructive and plastic surgeon at the American University of Beirut Medical Center.
item.content:encoded:
How do you heal the wounds of war? That is the mission of Dr. Ghassan Abu-Sittah, a reconstructive and plastic surgeon at the American University of Beirut Medical Center.

(Image credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: The GOP is shying away from town halls. This Missouri congressman is doing 15 of them
item.description: At a time when Congressional Republicans are generally opting against town halls, Missouri Rep. Mark Alford is embarking on a four-day, 15-stop tour to meet with constituents.
item.content:encoded:
At a time when Congressional Republicans are generally opting against town halls, Missouri Rep. Mark Alford is embarking on a four-day, 15-stop tour to meet with constituents.

(Image credit: AP Photo/Charlie Riedel))
item.dc:creator: Barbara Sprunt

item.title: Are you a new grandparent? NPR wants to hear from you for National Grandparent's Day
item.description: National Grandparents Day is Sep. 7. NPR wants to hear from new grandparents about how your life has changed.
item.content:encoded:
National Grandparents Day is Sep. 7. NPR wants to hear from new grandparents about how your life has changed.

(Image credit: Elise Amendola)
item.dc:creator: Suzanne Nuyen

item.title: In the brain, a lost limb is never really gone
item.description: Even years after an arm is amputated, the brain maintains a detailed map of the limb and tries to interact with this phantom appendage.
item.content:encoded:
Even years after an arm is amputated, the brain maintains a detailed map of the limb and tries to interact with this phantom appendage.

(Image credit: Westend61)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: Drowning prevention program comes to a halt at the CDC
item.description: A few years in, a CDC drowning prevention program was ready to share its findings on how to mitigate the leading cause of death among young children. Then the administration terminated that staff.
item.content:encoded: A few years in, a CDC drowning prevention program was ready to share its findings on how to mitigate the leading cause of death among young children. Then the administration terminated that staff.
item.dc:creator: Pien Huang

item.title: Hurricane Katrina forced changes at FEMA. Trump is rolling them back
item.description: The government's colossal failure to respond after Hurricane Katrina led to major reforms at the nation's top disaster agency. Now, the Trump administration has reversed some of those changes.
item.content:encoded:
The government's colossal failure to respond after Hurricane Katrina led to major reforms at the nation's top disaster agency. Now, the Trump administration has reversed some of those changes.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Hersher

item.title: Flag burning has a long history in the U.S. â€” and legal protections from the Supreme Court
item.description: President Trump's executive order challenges a landmark Supreme Court decision, according to free speech attorneys.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump's executive order challenges a landmark Supreme Court decision, according to free speech attorneys.

(Image credit: AFP/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez
